original_content:
How do you use a 3D printer to bend metal? One way would be to take it to a machine shop and offer to trade the owner your printer for some time in their shop. A smarter way is to do like [Jaba 3D], and print dies using the printer. You can then use those dies in a press to make the shapes you want.
In the case of [Jaba], the Harbor Freight press uses a hydraulic cylinder to develop about 6 tons of pressure. We dont think Harbor Freight carries this particular press, but for between $150 and $250, you can get a 12-20 ton press, and, of course, there are other suppliers, as well.
The target object, in this case, was an automotive bracket. The process of grabbing an image, converting it to an SVG, and then creating a 3D part has many uses. Apparently, PLA is sufficient for this purpose, although the print uses ten top and bottom layers along with 80% infill. That does make the prints take a long time.
As you might expect, the dies dont last very long. In this case, they needed two shots, and they got them, but PLA is probably not the right material if you wanted to go for mass production.
Metal forming does occur at large scales, too. If you want to make your own press-forming tools, we have advice for you.
title: 「3Dプリンターを使った金属の曲げ方」
body: 3Dプリンターを使用して金属を曲げる方法について説明。ハードウェアスポットの機械工房を利用しない方法として、3Dプリンターで型を作り、プレスで形を作る手法が紹介されている。プリンターには耐久性のある材料が必要で、大量生産には向かない。
titles: 「3Dプリンターを使った金属の曲げ方」
「ハイドロプレスを使用した自家製の金属成形」
「[Jaba 3D]が使用したハーバーフレートプレス」
「自動車のブラケットを作るための3Dプリントディー」
「金属成形におけるプリント素材の選択と耐久性」
